title: Revere's Shop
caption: Paul Revere’s silversmith shop was on Clark’s Wharf, a few blocks away from his home in North Square. He produced everything from silver spoons to tea sets. He also advertised as a dentist, wiring in false teeth made from animal teeth or walrus ivory and cleaning teeth.  Image courtesy of The Massachusetts Historical Society.

title: Ropewalks
caption: Long, narrow rope making facilities, known as ropewalks, thrived in 18th-century Boston. Ships, and the industry built around them, relied on a steady supply of rope. Look closely at the map for other kinds of industry in 1769 Boston, from mills to still houses (rum distilleries).

title: Map Cartouche
caption: In the decorative cartouche imagery in the top right corner of the map, a Native American watches a struggle between a British supporter (a Tory) and an advocate of American independence. They both want control of a liberty pole to determine the true champion of liberty. On the top of the liberty pole is a Phrygian cap, a symbol of freedom that refers to the caps worn by freed slaves in the Roman Empire. The Tory holds a flag with a lion, representing the British monarchy. The American attached his flag, which depicts Boston’s Liberty Tree, to the liberty pole.

title: Boston Public Library
caption: This is where the Boston Public Library is located in the present-day. The library first opened to the public in 1848 and moved to its current Copley Square location in 1895.

title: Boston's Neck
caption: Boston neck was the only land route in and out of Boston at the time of the American Revolution. During particularly high tides, it was prone to flooding and could temporarily turn the peninsula into an island. Note the fortification shown there. Originally a wooden gate, British forces added an earthenworks fortification in 1774. Since the surrounding area was soft mud, it was impossible to pass into the town this way on foot except through the fortification, thus easily sealing Boston off from the mainland.

title: Cambridge Headquarters
caption: George Washington established the headquarters of the colonial forces in Cambridge in July 1775 after being appointed Commander-in-Chief by the Second Continental Congress. Headquartered here for 8 months, Washington spent part of this time in the present-day Longfellow House at 105 Brattle Street. It is open to the public and run by the National Park Service as a historic site.

title: Crispus Attucks
caption: Crispus Attucks was the first to be killed during the Boston Massacre and is widely considered to be the first American casualty in the Revolutionary War. Attucks was a former slave who was believed to have been the son of a Black father and a Natick or Nantucket Indian mother.  Image of the Old State House in 1793 courtesy of Boston Public Library, Print Department.

title: Coffins of the Victims
caption: Engraved by Paul Revere, this print from the Boston Gazette was published on March 12, 1770. It shows four coffins with skull and crossbones as well as the initials of four men who were killed during the Boston Massacre: Samuel Gray, Samuel Maverick, James Caldwell, and Crispus Attucks.

title: Trade Routes
caption: This map demonstrates the triangular trade routes established between Africa, the Caribbean, and the colonies to support a high demand for rum, sugar, and slaves in Europe and the colonies during the 17th and 18th centuries.

title: The London Exchange
caption: London was the political and economic center of the British Empire. Merchants from throughout the empire gathered in the London Exchange to buy and sell goods. Colonial traders  depended on news and prices from the Exchange to sell their goods.

title: Library Stamp
caption: The Boston Public Library, like many libraries in the 19th and early 20th centuries, marked its holdings with a permanent stamp or embossed seal to deter anyone from stealing and selling the items. Modern Library Science practices discourage permanent markings like this on historic items.

title: Royals Bay
caption: The Royall family owned a sugar plantation in Royals Bay on the northern shore of Antigua that supported their estate in Medford, Massachusetts. They owned slaves who performed the arduous work of growing sugar cane.

title: Sugar Plantations
caption: Slaves worked on sugar plantations that thrived on Caribbean Islands like Antigua. European nations colonized the islands to produce the profitable commodity during the 17th and 18th centuries. The rise of these plantations made sugar available to the masses, rather than just elites.

title: Royall House
caption: Isaac Royall, Sr., an Antigua sugar plantation owner, moved to Massachusetts after purchasing this property on the Mystic River. He expanded the farmhouse originally owned by Massachusetts Governor John Winthrop into a three-story mansion. He also constructed separate quarters for the twenty-seven enslaved Africans the family brought with them. These slave quarters are the last standing in New England and are open to visitors.

title: Tufts University
caption: Officially chartered in 1852 with land gifted by Boston businessman Charles Tufts, Tufts University is located on one of the highest hills in the Boston area, Walnut Hill, in Medford.

title: Rock Salt
caption: A note describes East Taguza, the main salt-mining center of the Western Sahara located in present-day Mali. The site was an important source of rock salt for West Africa and the industry was vital to trans-Saharan trade in the late 16th century.

title: Trade Competition
caption: This note says: “The French had excluded the English from the Trade of this Coast to which they had a right.” Maps may not initially seem political, this note reveals the competition among European powers to gain control of the African coast, where traders sought gold, slaves, and other commodities.

title: Phillis Wheatley
caption: Phillis Wheatley, the first published African-American poet, is believed to have from the area of modern Senegal in Western Africa. She was captured and enslaved around the age of 7 and brought to Boston on the Phillis, the slave ship after which she was named.

title: Map Cartouche
caption: This cartouche in the bottom right features allegorical images of the commercial productivity of Britain’s North American empire. On the left is a coastal settlement. Barrels, possibly filled with molasses or tobacco, wait to be loaded onto the ship in the background. The title is framed by a palm tree and stalks of maize or corn, with a draped fishing net and beaver at the bottom. Two Native American figures, who represent America, wear headdresses and gaze upward at the title. The title is crowned by the royal crest and British flag, which signifies America’s dependence on Britain for protection and leadership.

title: Mohawks
caption: Mitchell’s map labels the colonies, but it also identifies the lands occupied by Native American tribes like the Mohawks. The map depicts the intermingling of colonists and Native Americans, who formed alliances with both sides during the Revolutionary War.

title: Map Cartouche
caption: The cartouche in the bottom right corner depicts a bucolic Hudson River scene. Small hills flank both sides of the river, where sailboats skim the water. Shrubs and trees dot the landscape on the banks of the Hudson. The compass rose symbolizes the sun, which shines over the lush landscape. The cartouche represents this region as an idyllic countryside.

title: New York City
caption: This map shows what New York City looked like during the British occupation of the city during the Revolutionary War.

title: Map Cartouche
caption: In the bottom right, the finely engraved cartouche by artist Francis Hayman depicts a dock scene. British merchant ships wait in the harbor for colonial goods to be loaded onto them. Three wealthy men, likely Virginia plantation owners, gather. One negotiates with a ship captain. Four enslaved Africans perform tasks; one serves wine to a planter, while three others prepare to load tobacco hogsheads on the awaiting ship. Virginia’s most important commodity was tobacco, and the colony’s economy was built upon slave labor. This scene shows the wealth and oppression in the colonies created by promise of profits from the tobacco trade.

title: Future Site of the Capital
caption: This area at the confluence of the Potomac and Anacostia Rivers later became the site of Washington, DC. During the early years of the republic, Thomas Jefferson and his supporters agreed that the nation would take on state debts incurred during the Revolutionary War in exchange for the mid-Atlantic capital site selected by George Washington.

title: Map Cartouche
caption: The cartouche in the bottom right depicts enslaved Africans making indigo, an export on which the South Carolina’s colonial economy was built. Indigo was used to make blue dye for clothing. Since blue was the most popular clothing color of the eighteenth century, indigo was a valuable commodity. Beneath two large palm trees, male slaves perform tasks on a plantation to prepare the indigo for sale. Nearby are plants, fruits, and vegetables that represent the area’s agriculture.

title: Savannah, Georgia
caption: Savannah is America's first planned city. The city’s founder, General James Oglethorpe laid the city out in a series of grids that allowed for wide open streets and several business and social areas.

title: Louisbourg Fortress
caption: The details of Louisbourg Fortress shows the positions of batteries of canon and mortar within and outside the fortress, described in detail in the key.

title: Early Map of Canada
caption: This map was prepared 33 years before the first printed map was produced in Canada and it is therefore one of the earliest maps made of the area.

title: Fur Trade and Fishing
caption: Britain was very interested in maintaining control of this region because the exportation of furs and codfish generated sizable income for merchants back in England. Profitable natural resources were abundant in Canada, as suggested by the placement of a North American beaver atop the cartouche, and the detailed depiction of the fishing banks off the coast of Newfoundland and Nova Scotia.

title: Shift to British Names
caption: Holland’s surveyed St. John’s Island – modern-day Prince Edward Island – as his first task performed for The General Survey of North America, where systematic surveys were executed according to the latest scientific principles. French and indigenous place names were changed to commemorate British royal figures, expressing the Empire’s power in the region.

title: Importance of Fishing
caption: Exemplified by the intricately drawn cartouche on this map, fishing was an extremely important industry in this area. Holland received specific instructions from the Board of Trade, to divide the island into a grid-system of counties, parishes, and townships of uniform size to make trade and industry more efficient.

title: Disneyworld
caption: This is where Walt Disney World opened in 1971 in Bay Lake, Florida. The park, designed by Walt Disney himself, was built as a supplement to Disneyland in Anaheim, California, which opened in 1955.

title: St. Augustine
caption: St. Augustine is the oldest continuously occupied European-established settlement and port in the continental United States.

title: Charlestown Burning
caption: Over 2,000 British soldiers landed on the shore of Charlestown during the Battle of Bunker Hill and quickly fired incendiary ammunition into the town. The town was quickly set on fire, providing a horrible background to the battle that was raging.

title: Logan Airport
caption: Eventually this area became Logan International Airport which opened in 1923 on a tiny airfield on Jeffries Point in East Boston.

title: Castle Island
caption: Castle Island served as a refuge for British authorities during the tumultuous period leading to the Revolution and British soldiers were forced here after the Boston Massacre in 1770. After the British evacuated Boston, they renamed it Fort Independence and Paul Revere was in command of the post from 1778 to 1779 as a lieutenant colonel of militia.

title: Watertown
caption: Watertown was the center of Revolutionary activity during the siege of Boston from 1775 to 1776. The Committees of Safety and Correspondence (essentially governing bodies in charge of the colonial militias) made this their headquarters for a time in 1775. Many Patriot families who had left their homes behind in Boston resided here during the siege, including Paul Revere’s.

title: Lexington and Concord
caption: The march of the British regiments back to Boston after the Battles of Lexington and Concord is shown on this map. The mapmaker notes the “Provincials firing behind the walls” to illustrate the tactic of the Minutemen firing at the Redcoats from behind trees, stone walls, houses and sheds.

title: Encampment on the Common
caption: Boston Common, the oldest public park in the country, originally overlooked Back Bay. During Revolution, the Common had trenches, artillery, and a powder house and during the winter of 1775-76 about 1,700 British soldiers camped out there in preparation for a possible attack by George Washington and his troops.

title: New Landscape
caption: Pelham engraved the pass issued to him two months after the Battle of Bunkers-Hill, giving him permission to examine the enemy lines. Pelham described the landscape in and around Boston during the Siege in a letter to his brother-in-law John Singleton Copley in January 1776:  “Not a Hillock 6 feet high but What is entrench’d, not a pass where a man could go but what is defended by Cannon;fences pulled down, houses removed, Woods grubed up, Fields cut into trenches and molded into Ramparts.”

title: Ralph Inman
caption: Ralph Inman was a prominent Boston merchant and noted Loyalist during the revolution. He married businesswoman Elizabeth Murray in 1771. Inman fled to Boston during the siege, while Murray stayed in Cambridge to protect their estate. Inman Square in Cambridge is named for him.

title: Harvard University
caption: Established in 1636, Harvard is the country’s oldest institution of higher learning. It was originally called “New College” and was changed to “Harvard College” in 1639 for its first benefactor, prominent clergyman John Harvard. Over the years the campus has greatly expanded and officially took the name “Harvard University” in 1900.

title: Maps Overlaid
caption: Interactive layers of information on maps is a common feature in the digital age, but fairly novel for the 18th century. Thomas Page included an innovative overlay on this map that allowed the viewer to view the initial attack that was repulsed. When removed, the area beneath the overlay shows the later progress of the British troops up the hill.

title: Breeds and Bunker Hills
caption: On June 16, 1775, American forces were under orders to fortify Bunker Hill, a 110 foot hill in Charlestown, but instead choose to fortify the smaller, but closer to Boston, Breed’s Hill. The ensuing bloody battle with British forces on June 17 became known as the Battle of Bunker Hill, although the action took place on Breed’s Hill.

title: Newport, Rhode Island
caption: Rhode Island played a major role in the slave trade with Newport as one of the major centers. By the end of the 18th century, Rhode Island had mounted at least 1,000 voyages from Africa to the Americas. Newport was also home to the 1763 Touro synagogue, one of the oldest synagogues in the United States. It is still an active place of worship today.

title: Brown University
caption: Brown University was founded in 1764, the third college in New England and the seventh in Colonial America. At the time this map was made, it was called the College of Rhode Island, a name it would keep until changing to Brown in 1804.

title: Oysters
caption: Oysters were a staple of the colonial diet, just as they were a staple of coastal Native American’s diet. While they have an expensive reputation today, they were affordable to poor city dwellers as well as the rich.

title: Location of Central Park
caption: While lower Manhattan was densely settled in the 18th century, the area where Central Park is today was more pastoral. It had an irregular terrain of swamps, bluffs, and rocky areas with few residents.

title: Manuscript Map
caption: This is a particularly great example of a manuscript map. Note the visible individual brush strokes that represent the slope of a hill.  Many of the small details on this map indicate the methods the map maker used to illustrate map features.

title: Hachuring
caption: These lines that radiate from high to low ground, called hachures, were a common way for a map maker to illustrate elevation change in the 18th century.  Here these lines are a telltale sign that this map is a manuscript, or an original drawing of the battles of Saratoga.

title: Fine Details
caption: When looking at the ships floating in Chesapeake Bay the details of an engraved map are apparent.  The fine printed lines that make many of these ships unique are not found on similar manuscript maps, where artist's hand drawn features are created with paint and ink.

title: Map Cartouche
caption: In the top right corner of the map, two heralds hold an open book labeled the “Rights of Man.” The title refers to a book of the same name published in 1791 by Thomas Paine. He argued that citizens have the right to rebel against a government that does not protect their rights. One herald blows a trumpet announcing the establishment of the national capital. The other holds a liberty pole. A shield features two stripes and three stars, the design of the coat of arms for George Washington’s family. The city adopted the design for its flag in the early twentieth century.

title: White House
caption: This map of Washington gives the locations for recognizable landmarks. Ellicott notes the President’s House at the intersection at several major streets. We now refer to this landmark as the White House. President Theodore Roosevelt made the White House the official name in 1901.

title: Frontier
caption: Marietta, a town on the banks of the Ohio River is the only major town on this map.  In the late 18th Century Ohio was part of what was considered the frontier, before the state was surveyed for settlement and populations in the east started moving west.

title: Gideon Hawley
caption: This plan of the Mashpee Reservation was made by an amateur mapmaker. Gideon Hawley, a Christian missionary to the Mashpee Indians, drew this map for Reverend Isaac Smith in 1785. Hawley likely created the boundaries based on his own survey of the landscape.

title: Hawley's Manuscript
caption: Gideon Hawley drew this map by hand. The manuscript contrasts with many of the printed maps in the exhibition. Even those printed maps, however, were based on original hand-drawn surveys like this one.

title: Mashpee Meeting House
caption: Gideon Hawley documented a Meeting House on the Mashpee land. Meeting Houses were an important part of New England politics and culture. Next to the Meeting House, Hawley noted that the Mashpee land included about 80 homes and 450 people.

title: United States and France
caption: Lattré’s map has a ship cartouche in the bottom right. The ship refers to the importance of French naval support for America’s victory. A sailor hangs from the sails symbols of the United States, including the Great Seal of the United States and the insignia of the Society of the Cincinnati (a hereditary society founded by Continental Army officers). On the right, a liberty pole and cap poke out from the sail. These symbols emphasize that the United States and France are champions of freedom. On the right, a trident (the weapon of the Poseidon, the powerful classical god of the sea) signifies French naval power.

title: New Lines, Old Survey
caption: Lattré based his map on John Mitchell’s 1755 map of North America, the most authoritative map of the colonial period. Mapmakers did not necessarily base their maps on new surveys, they sometimes copied existing maps. Lattré added new information by tracing the boundaries of the new nation and its states.

title: Florida and the Bahamas
caption: Compare the outlines of Florida and the Bahamas on this map and the modern map. You can see that they differ greatly. Florida was not yet part of the United States  differ from those on modern maps.

title: Iconic Cartouche
caption: The decorative cartouche imagery in the lower right establishes the new iconography of the United States. The map features prominent political figures George Washington and Benjamin Franklin. Allegorical female figures, including Liberty and her liberty pole and the blindfolded Justice, also appear. The classical goddess Athena, who wears a helmet, symbolizes wisdom. Above the figures, a herald with a trumpet and laurel wreath (representing victory) announces the birth of the new nation symbolized by the American flag.

title: New Western Limits
caption: The Mississippi River became the new western boundary (colored green) of the United States. Under British rule, the Proclamation of 1763 had established this boundary closer to the east coast, along the Appalachians. This older line separated colonial settlements from Native American territories. On this map it is colored orange and labeled as the “Antient [Ancient] Boundary of the Back Settlements or Indian Nations.”

title: Louisiana Purchase
caption: West of the Mississippi River, the early national boundary, is a Spanish territory labeled Louisiana. During Napoleon’s reign, France won this land from Spain. President Thomas Jefferson purchased the Louisiana Territory from Napoleon and made it part of the United States in 1803.

title: Odd State Boundaries
caption: After negotiating the boundaries of the United States with Great Britain, the new states had to negotiate their boundaries with each other. This map reflects the confusion over the new state boundaries. For example, the shape of New York State looks very different from its modern configuration. Maine and Vermont are not included because they were not yet states.

title: Niagara Falls
caption: The cartouche depicts Niagara Falls, which represented the sublime, untamed landscape of the United States. Two Native Americans converse near the top of the falls.

title: New Western State Boundaries
caption: After the establishment of the United States, the states began to negotiate firmer boundaries for their territories. Georgia claimed that their land extended west all the way to the Mississippi River, which included modern-day Alabama and Mississippi.
